description: Borrowed from Middle French commerce, from Latin commercium.

entries.meaning: (business) The exchange or buying and selling of commodities; especially the exchange of merchandise, on a large scale, between different places or communities; extended trade or traffic.
Social intercourse; the dealings of one person or class in society with another; familiarity.
examples: Suppose we held our converse not in words, but in music; those who have a bad ear would find themselves cut off from all near commerce, and no better than foreigners in this big world.
these perillous commerces of our love

entries.meaning: An 18th-century French card game in which the cards are subject to exchange, barter, or trade.

verbs.description: commerce (third-person singular simple present commerces, present participle commercing, simple past and past participle commerced)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, archaic) To carry on trade; to traffic.
examples: Beware you commerce not with bankrupts.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, archaic) To hold conversation; to communicate.
examples: Musicians  [â€¦]  taught the people in angelic harmonies to commerce with heaven.
